- It mentions Richmond having a home team score of 9.10 (64).
- It says Richmond is the away team's opponent for Melbourne's home game.

2. Second row: Collingwood vs Fitzroy
3. Third row: Carlton vs North Melbourne
4. Fourth row: Richmond (home) vs Melbourne (away)

But the claim says Richmond has a home team score of 9.10 (64). Looking through all rows, the only score close to that is in the fifth row where Footscray scored 9.10 (64) as the home team against Essendon as the away team. But that's not related to Melbourne.

Wait a minute, perhaps I misread. Let me check again. The claim says Richmond has a home score of 9.10 (64). In the table, in row four, Richmond is the home team with 15.19 (109), so that doesn't match. There's no other row where Richmond is the home team except row four.

So according to the claim, Richmond as a home team should have a score of 9.10 (64). But in reality, their home score was higher: 15.19 (109). Therefore, this part of the claim is incorrect.

Additionally, the claim says that Richmond is away team Melbourne's opponent. Wait, no—Melbourne is listed as the away team in row four when Richmond is home. So in that case, Melbourne isn't playing at their own home; instead, they're the away team against Richmond's home game.

So putting it all together:
- The claim states that Richmond has a home score of 9.10 (64), but the table shows their home score as higher.
- Also, Melbourne is an away team in row four, not at their own venue.
